speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. A street.

speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
text_entry: Enter a company of mutinous Citizens, with staves, clubs, and other weapons

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

speaker: All
text_entry: Speak, speak.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

speaker: All
text_entry: Resolved. resolved.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.

speaker: All
text_entry: We know't, we know't.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Is't a verdict?

speaker: All
text_entry: No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: One word, good citizens.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: What authority surfeits on would relieve us: if they

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: would yield us but the superfluity, while it were

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely;

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: but they think we are too dear: the leanness that

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: inventory to particularise their abundance; our

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: sufferance is a gain to them Let us revenge this with

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: our pikes, ere we become rakes: for the gods know I

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?

speaker: All
text_entry: Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Consider you what services he has done for his country?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Very well; and could be content to give him good

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: report fort, but that he pays himself with being proud.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Nay, but speak not maliciously.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: it to that end: though soft-conscienced men can be

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: content to say it was for his country he did it to

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: please his mother and to be partly proud; which he

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: is, even till the altitude of his virtue.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: What he cannot help in his nature, you account a

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations;

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Shouts within

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: What shouts are these? The other side o' the city

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: is risen: why stay we prating here? to the Capitol!

speaker: All
text_entry: Come, come.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Soft! who comes here?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Enter MENENIUS AGRIPPA

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: the people.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: He's one honest enough: would all the rest were so!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: What work's, my countrymen, in hand? where go you

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: With bats and clubs? The matter? speak, I pray you.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Our business is not unknown to the senate; they have

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do,

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: which now we'll show 'em in deeds. They say poor

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: suitors have strong breaths: they shall know we

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: have strong arms too.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Will you undo yourselves?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: We cannot, sir, we are undone already.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I tell you, friends, most charitable care

text_entry: Have the patricians of you. For your wants,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well

text_entry: Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Against the Roman state, whose course will on

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Of more strong link asunder than can ever

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,

text_entry: The gods, not the patricians, make it, and

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: established against the rich, and provide more

text_entry: piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain

text_entry: the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will; and

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Either you must

text_entry: Confess yourselves wondrous malicious,

text_entry: Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you

text_entry: A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: To stale 't a little more.

text_entry: Well, I'll hear it, sir: yet you must not think to

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, an 't please

speaker: First Citizen

text_entry: Your most grave belly was deliberate,

text_entry: Nor did you think it folly

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: To keep your great pretences veil'd till when

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: They needs must show themselves; which

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: in the hatching,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: It seem'd, appear'd to Rome. By the discovery.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: We shall be shorten'd in our aim, which was

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: To take in many towns ere almost Rome

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Should know we were afoot.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Noble Aufidius,

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Take your commission; hie you to your bands:

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Let us alone to guard Corioli:

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: If they set down before 's, for the remove

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Bring your army; but, I think, you'll find

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: They've not prepared for us.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: O, doubt not that;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I speak from certainties. Nay, more,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Some parcels of their power are forth already,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And only hitherward. I leave your honours.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: 'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Till one can do no more.

speaker: All
text_entry: The gods assist you!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And keep your honours safe!

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Farewell.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Farewell.

speaker: All
text_entry: Farewell.

speaker: All
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: All
text_entry: SCENE III. Rome. A room in Marcius' house.

speaker: All
text_entry: Enter VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA they set them down on two low stools, and sew

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: I pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself in a

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: more comfortable sort: if my son were my husband, I

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: won honour than in the embracements of his bed where

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: he would show most love. When yet he was but

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, when

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way, when

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: for a day of kings' entreaties a mother should not

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: sell him an hour from her beholding, I, considering

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: how honour would become such a person. that it was

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: no better than picture-like to hang by the wall, if

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: renown made it not stir, was pleased to let him seek

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: danger where he was like to find fame. To a cruel

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: war I sent him; from whence he returned, his brows

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: than now in first seeing he had proved himself a

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: man.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: But had he died in the business, madam; how then?

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Then his good report should have been my son; I

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: therein would have found issue. Hear me profess

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my love

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: alike and none less dear than thine and my good

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Marcius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Enter a Gentlewoman

speaker: Gentlewoman
text_entry: Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Indeed, you shall not.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: See him pluck Aufidius down by the hair,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus:

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: 'Come on, you cowards! you were got in fear,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Though you were born in Rome:' his bloody brow

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: With his mail'd hand then wiping, forth he goes,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Like to a harvest-man that's task'd to mow

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Or all or lose his hire.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: His bloody brow! O Jupiter, no blood!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Away, you fool! it more becomes a man

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Than gilt his trophy: the breasts of Hecuba,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: When she did suckle Hector, look'd not lovelier

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: At Grecian sword, contemning. Tell Valeria,

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: We are fit to bid her welcome.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Exit Gentlewoman

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: He'll beat Aufidius 'head below his knee

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: And tread upon his neck.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Enter VALERIA, with an Usher and Gentlewoman

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: My ladies both, good day to you.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Sweet madam.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: I am glad to see your ladyship.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: How do you both? you are manifest house-keepers.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: What are you sewing here? A fine spot, in good

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: faith. How does your little son?

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: I thank your ladyship; well, good madam.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: He had rather see the swords, and hear a drum, than

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: look upon his school-master.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: O' my word, the father's son: I'll swear,'tis a

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: very pretty boy. O' my troth, I looked upon him o'

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Wednesday half an hour together: has such a

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: confirmed countenance. I saw him run after a gilded

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: butterfly: and when he caught it, he let it go

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: again; and after it again; and over and over he

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: comes, and again; catched it again; or whether his

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: fall enraged him, or how 'twas, he did so set his

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: teeth and tear it; O, I warrant it, how he mammocked

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: it!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: One on 's father's moods.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Indeed, la, 'tis a noble child.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: A crack, madam.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Come, lay aside your stitchery; I must have you play

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: the idle husewife with me this afternoon.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: No, good madam; I will not out of doors.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Not out of doors!

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: She shall, she shall.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: Indeed, no, by your patience; I'll not over the

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: threshold till my lord return from the wars.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably: come,

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: you must go visit the good lady that lies in.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: my prayers; but I cannot go thither.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Why, I pray you?

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: You would be another Penelope: yet, they say, all

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did but fill

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Ithaca full of moths. Come; I would your cambric

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: were sensible as your finger, that you might leave

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go with us.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: No, good madam, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: In truth, la, go with me; and I'll tell you

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: excellent news of your husband.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: O, good madam, there can be none yet.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: him last night.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: Indeed, madam?

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: whom Cominius the general is gone, with one part of

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: our Roman power: your lord and Titus Lartius are set

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: down before their city Corioli; they nothing doubt

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: prevailing and to make it brief wars. This is true,

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: on mine honour; and so, I pray, go with us.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in every

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: thing hereafter.

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: Let her alone, lady: as she is now, she will but

speaker: VOLUMNIA
text_entry: disease our better mirth.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: In troth, I think she would. Fare you well, then.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Come, good sweet lady. Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: solemness out o' door. and go along with us.

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: No, at a word, madam; indeed, I must not. I wish

speaker: VIRGILIA
text_entry: you much mirth.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Well, then, farewell.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: SCENE IV. Before Corioli.

speaker: VALERIA
text_entry: Enter, with drum and colours, MARCIUS, TITUS  LARTIUS, Captains and Soldiers. To them a Messenger

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Yonder comes news. A wager they have met.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: My horse to yours, no.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: 'Tis done.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Agreed.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Say, has our general met the enemy?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They lie in view; but have not spoke as yet.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: So, the good horse is mine.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: I'll buy him of you.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: No, I'll nor sell nor give him: lend you him I will

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: For half a hundred years. Summon the town.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: How far off lie these armies?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Within this mile and half.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: That we with smoking swords may march from hence,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: They sound a parley. Enter two Senators with others on the walls

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Tutus Aufidius, is he within your walls?

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: No, nor a man that fears you less than he,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: That's lesser than a little.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Drums afar off

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Hark! our drums

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Rather than they shall pound us up: our gates,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Which yet seem shut, we, have but pinn'd with rushes;

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: They'll open of themselves.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Alarum afar off

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Hark you. far off!

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: There is Aufidius; list, what work he makes

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Amongst your cloven army.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: O, they are at it!

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Their noise be our instruction. Ladders, ho!

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Enter the army of the Volsces

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: They fear us not, but issue forth their city.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: With hearts more proof than shields. Advance,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: brave Titus:

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fellows:

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: He that retires I'll take him for a Volsce,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: And he shall feel mine edge.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Alarum. The Romans are beat back to their trenches. Re-enter MARCIUS cursing

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: All the contagion of the south light on you,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: You shames of Rome! you herd of--Boils and plagues

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorr'd

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Further than seen and one infect another

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: That bear the shapes of men, how have you run

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: All hurt behind; backs red, and faces pale

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: And make my wars on you: look to't: come on;

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: If you'll stand fast, we'll beat them to their wives,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: As they us to our trenches followed.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Another alarum. The Volsces fly, and MARCIUS follows them to the gates

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: So, now the gates are ope: now prove good seconds:

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: 'Tis for the followers fortune widens them,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Not for the fliers: mark me, and do the like.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Enters the gates

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Fool-hardiness; not I.

speaker: Second Soldier
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: Second Soldier
text_entry: MARCIUS is shut in

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: See, they have shut him in.

speaker: All
text_entry: To the pot, I warrant him.

speaker: All
text_entry: Alarum continues

speaker: All
text_entry: Re-enter TITUS LARTIUS

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: What is become of Marcius?

speaker: All
text_entry: Slain, sir, doubtless.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Following the fliers at the very heels,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: With them he enters; who, upon the sudden,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Clapp'd to their gates: he is himself alone,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: To answer all the city.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: O noble fellow!

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword,

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: And, when it bows, stands up. Thou art left, Marcius:

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art,

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Only in strokes; but, with thy grim looks and

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds,

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Thou madst thine enemies shake, as if the world

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Were feverous and did tremble.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Re-enter MARCIUS, bleeding, assaulted by the enemy

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Look, sir.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: O,'tis Marcius!

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Let's fetch him off, or make remain alike.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: They fight, and all enter the city

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: SCENE V. Corioli. A street.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Enter certain Romans, with spoils

speaker: First Roman
text_entry: This will I carry to Rome.

speaker: Second Roman
text_entry: And I this.

speaker: Third Roman
text_entry: A murrain on't! I took this for silver.

speaker: Third Roman
text_entry: Alarum continues still afar off

speaker: Third Roman
text_entry: Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS with a trumpet

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: See here these movers that do prize their hours

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: At a crack'd drachm! Cushions, leaden spoons,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them!

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: And hark, what noise the general makes! To him!

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Convenient numbers to make good the city;

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: To help Cominius.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Worthy sir, thou bleed'st;

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Thy exercise hath been too violent for

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: A second course of fight.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Sir, praise me not;

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: My work hath yet not warm'd me: fare you well:

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: The blood I drop is rather physical

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: I will appear, and fight.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Now the fair goddess, Fortune,

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman,

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Prosperity be thy page!

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Thy friend no less

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Than those she placeth highest! So, farewell.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Thou worthiest Marcius!

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Exit MARCIUS

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Go, sound thy trumpet in the market-place;

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Call thither all the officers o' the town,

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Where they shall know our mind: away!

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: SCENE VI. Near the camp of Cominius.

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Enter COMINIUS, as it were in retire, with soldiers

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Breathe you, my friends: well fought;

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: we are come off

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Nor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: We shall be charged again. Whiles we have struck,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: By interims and conveying gusts we have heard

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: The charges of our friends. Ye Roman gods!

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Lead their successes as we wish our own,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: That both our powers, with smiling

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: fronts encountering,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: May give you thankful sacrifice.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Thy news?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The citizens of Corioli have issued,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I saw our party to their trenches driven,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And then I came away.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Though thou speak'st truth,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Methinks thou speak'st not well.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: How long is't since?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Above an hour, my lord.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums:

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And bring thy news so late?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Spies of the Volsces

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Held me in chase, that I was forced to wheel

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Three or four miles about, else had I, sir,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Half an hour since brought my report.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Who's yonder,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: That does appear as he were flay'd? O gods

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: He has the stamp of Marcius; and I have

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Before-time seen him thus.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: [Within]                 Come I too late?

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabour

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: From every meaner man.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Enter MARCIUS

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Come I too late?

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: But mantled in your own.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: O, let me clip ye

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: In arms as sound as when I woo'd, in heart

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: As merry as when our nuptial day was done,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: And tapers burn'd to bedward!

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Flower of warriors,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: How is it with Titus Lartius?

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: As with a man busied about decrees:

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Condemning some to death, and some to exile;

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other;

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Holding Corioli in the name of Rome,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: To let him slip at will.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Where is that slave

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Where is he? call him hither.

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: Let him alone;

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen,

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: The common file--a plague! tribunes for them!--

speaker: MARCIUS
text_entry: The mouse ne'er shunn'd the cat as they did budge

text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. A public place.

text_entry: Enter MENENIUS with the two Tribunes of the people, SICINIUS and BRUTUS.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience:

speaker: MENENIUS

text_entry: could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks,

text_entry: and make but an interior survey of your good selves!

speaker: MENENIUS

text_entry: Come, come, you are well understood to be a

text_entry: Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall

text_entry: you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the

speaker: MENENIUS

text_entry: True! pow, wow.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Where is he wounded?

speaker: MENENIUS

speaker: MENENIUS

speaker: VOLUMNIA

speaker: MENENIUS

speaker: VOLUMNIA

speaker: First Officer
text_entry: That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and

speaker: First Officer

speaker: Second Officer

speaker: Second Officer

text_entry: I know you well, sir, and you know

speaker: Roman
text_entry: me: your name, I think, is Adrian.

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: It is so, sir: truly, I have forgot you.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: I am a Roman; and my services are,

speaker: Roman
text_entry: as you are, against 'em: know you me yet?

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: Nicanor? no.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: The same, sir.

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: You had more beard when I last saw you; but your

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: favour is well approved by your tongue. What's the

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: news in Rome? I have a note from the Volscian state,

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: to find you out there: you have well saved me a

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: day's journey.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: There hath been in Rome strange insurrections; the

speaker: Roman
text_entry: people against the senators, patricians, and nobles.

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: Hath been! is it ended, then? Our state thinks not

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: so: they are in a most warlike preparation, and

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: hope to come upon them in the heat of their division.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing

speaker: Roman
text_entry: would make it flame again: for the nobles receive

speaker: Roman
text_entry: so to heart the banishment of that worthy

speaker: Roman
text_entry: Coriolanus, that they are in a ripe aptness to take

speaker: Roman
text_entry: all power from the people and to pluck from them

speaker: Roman
text_entry: their tribunes for ever. This lies glowing, I can

speaker: Roman
text_entry: tell you, and is almost mature for the violent

speaker: Roman
text_entry: breaking out.

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: Coriolanus banished!

speaker: Roman
text_entry: Banished, sir.

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: The day serves well for them now. I have heard it

speaker: Roman
text_entry: said, the fittest time to corrupt a man's wife is

speaker: Roman
text_entry: when she's fallen out with her husband. Your noble

speaker: Roman
text_entry: Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his

speaker: Roman
text_entry: great opposer, Coriolanus, being now in no request

speaker: Roman
text_entry: of his country.

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: He cannot choose. I am most fortunate, thus

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: accidentally to encounter you: you have ended my

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: business, and I will merrily accompany you home.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: I shall, between this and supper, tell you most

speaker: Roman
text_entry: strange things from Rome; all tending to the good of

speaker: Roman
text_entry: their adversaries. Have you an army ready, say you?

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: A most royal one; the centurions and their charges,

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: distinctly billeted, already in the entertainment,

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: and to be on foot at an hour's warning.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: I am joyful to hear of their readiness, and am the

speaker: Roman
text_entry: man, I think, that shall set them in present action.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: So, sir, heartily well met, and most glad of your company.

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: You take my part from me, sir; I have the most cause

speaker: Volsce
text_entry: to be glad of yours.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: Well, let us go together.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Roman
text_entry: SCENE IV. Antium. Before Aufidius's house.

speaker: Roman
text_entry: Enter CORIOLANUS in mean apparel, disguised and muffled

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A goodly city is this Antium. City,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: 'Tis I that made thy widows: many an heir

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of these fair edifices 'fore my wars

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Have I heard groan and drop: then know me not,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: In puny battle slay me.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Enter a Citizen

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Save you, sir.

speaker: Citizen
text_entry: And you.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Direct me, if it be your will,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Where great Aufidius lies: is he in Antium?

speaker: Citizen
text_entry: He is, and feasts the nobles of the state

speaker: Citizen
text_entry: At his house this night.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which is his house, beseech you?

speaker: Citizen
text_entry: This, here before you.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thank you, sir: farewell.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Exit Citizen

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: O world, thy slippery turns! Friends now fast sworn,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Whose double bosoms seem to wear one heart,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Whose house, whose bed, whose meal, and exercise,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Are still together, who twin, as 'twere, in love

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Unseparable, shall within this hour,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: On a dissension of a doit, break out

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To bitterest enmity: so, fellest foes,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Whose passions and whose plots have broke their sleep,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To take the one the other, by some chance,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Some trick not worth an egg, shall grow dear friends

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And interjoin their issues. So with me:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My birth-place hate I, and my love's upon

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: This enemy town. I'll enter: if he slay me,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: He does fair justice; if he give me way,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I'll do his country service.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: SCENE V. The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Music within. Enter a Servingman

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Wine, wine, wine! What service

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: is here! I think our fellows are asleep.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Enter a second Servingman

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Where's Cotus? my master calls

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: for him. Cotus!

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Enter CORIOLANUS

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A goodly house: the feast smells well; but I

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Appear not like a guest.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Re-enter the first Servingman

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: What would you have, friend? whence are you?

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Here's no place for you: pray, go to the door.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I have deserved no better entertainment,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: In being Coriolanus.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Re-enter second Servingman

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Whence are you, sir? Has the porter his eyes in his

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: head; that he gives entrance to such companions?

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Pray, get you out.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Away!

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Away! get you away.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Now thou'rt troublesome.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Are you so brave? I'll have you talked with anon.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Enter a third Servingman. The first meets him

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: What fellow's this?

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: A strange one as ever I looked on: I cannot get him

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: out of the house: prithee, call my master to him.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Retires

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you, avoid

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: the house.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Let me but stand; I will not hurt your hearth.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: What are you?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A gentleman.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: A marvellous poor one.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: True, so I am.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: station; here's no place for you; pray you, avoid: come.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Pushes him away

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: What, you will not? Prithee, tell my master what a

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: strange guest he has here.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: And I shall.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Where dwellest thou?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Under the canopy.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Under the canopy!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Where's that?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I' the city of kites and crows.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: I' the city of kites and crows! What an ass it is!

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Then thou dwellest with daws too?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: No, I serve not thy master.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: How, sir! do you meddle with my master?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: mistress. Thou pratest, and pratest; serve with thy

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: trencher, hence!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Beats him away. Exit third Servingman

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Enter AUFIDIUS with the second Servingman

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Where is this fellow?

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Here, sir: I'ld have beaten him like a dog, but for

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: disturbing the lords within.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Retires

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Whence comest thou? what wouldst thou? thy name?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Why speak'st not? speak, man: what's thy name?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: If, Tullus,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Unmuffling

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Not yet thou knowest me, and, seeing me, dost not

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Think me for the man I am, necessity

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Commands me name myself.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: What is thy name?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And harsh in sound to thine.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Say, what's thy name?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thou hast a grim appearance, and thy face

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Bears a command in't; though thy tackle's torn.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thou show'st a noble vessel: what's thy name?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Prepare thy brow to frown: know'st

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: thou me yet?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I know thee not: thy name?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To thee particularly and to all the Volsces

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My surname, Coriolanus: the painful service,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The extreme dangers and the drops of blood

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Shed for my thankless country are requited

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: But with that surname; a good memory,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And witness of the malice and displeasure

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which thou shouldst bear me: only that name remains;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The cruelty and envy of the people,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Permitted by our dastard nobles, who

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Have all forsook me, hath devour'd the rest;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And suffer'd me by the voice of slaves to be

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Whoop'd out of Rome. Now this extremity

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hath brought me to thy hearth; not out of hope--

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Mistake me not--to save my life, for if

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I had fear'd death, of all the men i' the world

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I would have 'voided thee, but in mere spite,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To be full quit of those my banishers,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Stand I before thee here. Then if thou hast

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A heart of wreak in thee, that wilt revenge

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of shame seen through thy country, speed

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: thee straight,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And make my misery serve thy turn: so use it

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That my revengeful services may prove

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: As benefits to thee, for I will fight

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Against my canker'd country with the spleen

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of all the under fiends. But if so be

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thou darest not this and that to prove more fortunes

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thou'rt tired, then, in a word, I also am

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Longer to live most weary, and present

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which not to cut would show thee but a fool,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Since I have ever follow'd thee with hate,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Drawn tuns of blood out of thy country's breast,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And cannot live but to thy shame, unless

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: It be to do thee service.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: O Marcius, Marcius!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: A root of ancient envy. If Jupiter

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Should from yond cloud speak divine things,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And say 'Tis true,' I'ld not believe them more

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Than thee, all noble Marcius. Let me twine

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Mine arms about that body, where against

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My grained ash an hundred times hath broke

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And scarr'd the moon with splinters: here I clip

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The anvil of my sword, and do contest

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: As hotly and as nobly with thy love

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: As ever in ambitious strength I did

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Contend against thy valour. Know thou first,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I loved the maid I married; never man

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Sigh'd truer breath; but that I see thee here,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thou noble thing! more dances my rapt heart

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Than when I first my wedded mistress saw

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars! I tell thee,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: We have a power on foot; and I had purpose

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Or lose mine arm fort: thou hast beat me out

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Twelve several times, and I have nightly since

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: We have been down together in my sleep,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And waked half dead with nothing. Worthy Marcius,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Had we no quarrel else to Rome, but that

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thou art thence banish'd, we would muster all

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: From twelve to seventy, and pouring war

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Like a bold flood o'er-bear. O, come, go in,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And take our friendly senators by the hands;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Who now are here, taking their leaves of me,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Who am prepared against your territories,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Though not for Rome itself.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You bless me, gods!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The leading of thine own revenges, take

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The one half of my commission; and set down--

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: As best thou art experienced, since thou know'st

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thy country's strength and weakness,--thine own ways;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Whether to knock against the gates of Rome,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Or rudely visit them in parts remote,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: To fright them, ere destroy. But come in:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Let me commend thee first to those that shall

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And more a friend than e'er an enemy;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Yet, Marcius, that was much. Your hand: most welcome!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS. The two Servingmen come forward

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Here's a strange alteration!

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: false report of him.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: What an arm he has! he turned me about with his

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: finger and his thumb, as one would set up a top.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: him: he had, sir, a kind of face, methought,--I

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: cannot tell how to term it.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: He had so; looking as it were--would I were hanged,

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: but I thought there was more in him than I could think.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: So did I, I'll be sworn: he is simply the rarest

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: man i' the world.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: I think he is: but a greater soldier than he you wot on.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Who, my master?

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Nay, it's no matter for that.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Worth six on him.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Nay, not so neither: but I take him to be the

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: greater soldier.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that:

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: for the defence of a town, our general is excellent.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Ay, and for an assault too.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Re-enter third Servingman

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: O slaves, I can tell you news,-- news, you rascals!

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: What, what, what? let's partake.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: I would not be a Roman, of all nations; I had as

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: lieve be a condemned man.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Wherefore? wherefore?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general,

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Caius Marcius.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Why do you say 'thwack our general '?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: I do not say 'thwack our general;' but he was always

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: good enough for him.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Come, we are fellows and friends: he was ever too

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: hard for him; I have heard him say so himself.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: on't: before Corioli he scotched him and notched

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: him like a carbon ado.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: An he had been cannibally given, he might have

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: broiled and eaten him too.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: But, more of thy news?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Why, he is so made on here within, as if he were son

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' the table; no

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: question asked him by any of the senators, but they

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: stand bald before him: our general himself makes a

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: mistress of him: sanctifies himself with's hand and

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: turns up the white o' the eye to his discourse. But

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: the bottom of the news is that our general is cut i'

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: the middle and but one half of what he was

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: yesterday; for the other has half, by the entreaty

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: and grant of the whole table. He'll go, he says,

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: and sowl the porter of Rome gates by the ears: he

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: will mow all down before him, and leave his passage polled.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Do't! he will do't; for, look you, sir, he has as

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: many friends as enemies; which friends, sir, as it

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: were, durst not, look you, sir, show themselves, as

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: we term it, his friends whilst he's in directitude.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Directitude! what's that?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again,

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: and the man in blood, they will out of their

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: burrows, like conies after rain, and revel all with

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: him.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: But when goes this forward?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: To-morrow; to-day; presently; you shall have the

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: drum struck up this afternoon: 'tis, as it were, a

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: parcel of their feast, and to be executed ere they

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: wipe their lips.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Why, then we shall have a stirring world again.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: This peace is nothing, but to rust iron, increase

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: tailors, and breed ballad-makers.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as far as

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy;

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible; a getter of more

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: 'Tis so: and as war, in some sort, may be said to

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: be a ravisher, so it cannot be denied but peace is a

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: great maker of cuckolds.

speaker: First Servingman

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Reason; because they then less need one another.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: The wars for my money. I hope to see Romans as cheap

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: as Volscians. They are rising, they are rising.

speaker: All
text_entry: In, in, in, in!

speaker: All

speaker: All

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: The man is noble and his fame folds-in

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: This orb o' the earth. His last offences to us

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Shall have judicious hearing. Stand, Aufidius,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And trouble not the peace.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: O that I had him,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: With six Aufidiuses, or more, his tribe,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To use my lawful sword!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Insolent villain!

speaker: All Conspirators
text_entry: Kill, kill, kill, kill, kill him!

speaker: All Conspirators
text_entry: The Conspirators draw, and kill CORIOLANUS: AUFIDIUS stands on his body

speaker: Lords
text_entry: Hold, hold, hold, hold!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My noble masters, hear me speak.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: O Tullus,--

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Thou hast done a deed whereat valour will weep.

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: Tread not upon him. Masters all, be quiet;

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: Put up your swords.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My lords, when you shall know--as in this rage,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Provoked by him, you cannot--the great danger

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Which this man's life did owe you, you'll rejoice

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: That he is thus cut off. Please it your honours

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: To call me to your senate, I'll deliver

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Myself your loyal servant, or endure

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Your heaviest censure.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Bear from hence his body;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And mourn you for him: let him be regarded

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: As the most noble corse that ever herald

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Did follow to his urn.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: His own impatience

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Takes from Aufidius a great part of blame.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Let's make the best of it.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My rage is gone;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And I am struck with sorrow. Take him up.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Help, three o' the chiefest soldiers; I'll be one.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Beat thou the drum, that it speak mournfully:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Trail your steel pikes. Though in this city he

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Hath widow'd and unchilded many a one,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Which to this hour bewail the injury,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Yet he shall have a noble memory. Assist.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt, bearing the body of CORIOLANUS. A dead march sounded
